support_summary: ATXN3 directly deubiquitinates RNA polymerase II, preventing its degradation and thereby playing a role in transcription and DNA repair.

functions.function: RNA Polymerase II Stability and DNA Repair
functions.cellular_process: ATXN3 is a key component of the transcription-coupled DNA repair (TCR) pathway. It directly associates with the largest subunit of RNA polymerase II (RNAPII) and proteins of the classical nonhomologous end-joining (C-NHEJ) pathway. In response to DNA damage that stalls transcription, RNAPII can be ubiquitinated and targeted for degradation. ATXN3 counteracts this by deubiquitinating RNAPII.
functions.effect_description: By removing ubiquitin chains from RNAPII, ATXN3 prevents its proteasomal degradation. This stabilization is critical for allowing the DNA repair machinery to access and repair lesions in actively transcribed genes and for transcription to resume after repair, thereby maintaining genomic integrity.
biological_consequence: DNA damage occurs in a transcribed gene, stalling RNA Polymerase II -> RNAPII is poly-ubiquitinated for degradation -> ATXN3 is recruited to the complex -> ATXN3 deubiquitinates RNAPII -> RNAPII is stabilized and degradation is prevented -> Transcription-coupled DNA repair proceeds, followed by resumption of transcription.
specific_effects: Directly deubiquitinates the largest subunit of RNA polymerase II.
Prevents proteasomal degradation of RNA polymerase II, particularly in response to DNA damage.
Absence of ATXN3 leads to transcriptional blockage and unrepaired double-strand breaks in the transcribed genome.

evidence.paper_title: Deficiency in classical nonhomologous end-joining–mediated repair of transcribed genes is linked to SCA3 pathogenesis
evidence.journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the USA
evidence.relevant_quote: Here, we report that ATXN3 associates with RNA polymerase II (RNAP II) and the classical nonhomologous end-joining (C-NHEJ) proteins, including PNKP, along with nascent RNAs under physiological conditions.

evidence.paper_title: ATXN3: a multifunctional protein involved in the polyglutamine disease spinocerebellar ataxia type 3
evidence.relevant_quote: Moreover, as observed in both cellular models and Drosophila mutants, in the absence of ATXN3, PNKP inactivation results in the accumulation of persistent 3′-P termini, while RNA polymerase II, which is normally deubiquitinated by ATXN3, becomes poly-ubiquitinated and subsequently degraded. This causes transcriptional blockage and unrepaired DSB breaks in the transcribed genome.
